newsitem.title: USA: Sybase to renew most products in 1997 - CEO.
newsitem.headline: Sybase to renew most products in 1997 - CEO.

text.p: Sybase Inc, implementing a plan to recover from slowing sales growth, will renew most of its major products in 1997, the software company's chief executive said Wednesday.

Sybase, which writes computer programs to store and retrieve huge amounts of corporate information, also will unveil by the second quarter a product "architecture" to mor closely bind its products, said Mitchell Kertzman, Sybase CEO.
In the past two years, Sybase has been struggling because of increasing competition from its traditional rivals Oracle Corp and Informix Corp, as well as a new competitor, Microsoft Corp.
Kertzman in the past year has trimmed Sybase's product lines and cut jobs to focus the company on its core business of selling databases and software development tools.
"Our customers wanted a symphony and we were giving them a lot of jam sessions," Kertzman told investors at the Robertson Stephens & Co Technology Conference.
To counter rivals and grow the company's core business, Sybase will revamp many of its key products in 1997, including its flagship SQL Server, Kertzman said.
The company also will unveil a product architecture to more closely bind its databases and development tools, he said.
